meaning_mnemonic: Think about it this way. There is a famous fishing lure inventor, working on his best work ever. He’s old, and he’s been trying to make the best fishing lure for the last 50 years, and knows this will be his last invention. Then he figures it out. He takes one <radical>barb</radical>, and connects the end of it to the top of another <radical>barb</radical>. When he does this, he knows his work is finally <kanji>finish</kanji>ed.
meaning_hint: Make sure you look at this amazing fishing lure too - hold it in your hand, see the two barbs fused together. Think about how strange this lure is. Is this really the best in the world? Will this really finish all other fishing lures?
reading_mnemonic: How does the fish lure maker test his newly <kanji>finish</kanji>ed lure out? The one he just finished? He gets in a <reading>row</reading> (りょう) boat and rows out into the sea.
reading_hint: Make him think that he can’t just use his new lure on the side of the lake / ocean / whatever. He has to get out there, but unfortunately all he has is a crappy row boat. Imagine the row boat being terrible, leaky, and dangerous, which is why you’re surprised when he goes for it. That’s a terrible row boat to use! If you do this, you'll focus your mind on the rowboat part of things, which will help you to remember the reading of this kanji.

meaning_mnemonic: You have <radical>fins</radical> in <radical>private</radical>. But, you want the world to see them, so you take them <kanji>public</kanji>.
meaning_hint: Picture yourself in private, with fins. You wish others could see them. "That's it," you decide. "It's time to show the world. I'm going to make my fins public!"
reading_mnemonic: You head out into the <kanji>public</kanji> where everyone can see your fins, but... things have changed. All people are the same. There are thousands of <reading>こう</reading>いちs walking around, and they all stare at you (though they pretend like they aren't).
reading_hint: How long have you been hiding in private with your fins? The public areas have changed, and all the people have become こういちs. One mother こういち--pushing a baby こういち--looks up and stares at your fins. Now you remember why you never go out in public.

meaning_mnemonic: Let the <radical>sun</radical> shine into your <radical>ear</radical> while sitting on a <radical>stool</radical> and make sure <kanji>most</kanji> of it gets in your head. You want to fill your brain with the most sun anyone ever has.
meaning_hint: Most of the sun is getting into your ear, but not all of it. Darn, maybe you should try angling yourself a different way.
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Most</kanji> of this is for your <reading>cy</reading>borg (さい). You're testing out a new way to power it, but if you can't get most of the sun into your ear, it won't be enough to power most of the cyborg's robo-parts.
reading_hint: Install the part into your cyborg. As long as most of the sun gets into its human ear, most of its cyborg bits will have power.

meaning_mnemonic: If you give a <radical>woman</radical> a <radical>machine</radical> she'll <kanji>begin</kanji> learning how to use it right away. She'll also get it to <kanji>start</kanji> before anyone else could. Women are really good at starting up new machines!
meaning_hint: Picture a woman seeing a new machine and beginning work on it right away to see how she can start it up.
reading_mnemonic: Actually, before she can <kanji>begin</kanji>, she has to shear the <reading>shee</reading>p (し) over there. The machine is going to turn wool into yarn, but you can't just start that process by shoving the sheep in there. You have to keep the little sheep safe!
reading_hint: Picture a machine starting up as the woman begins to shear the sheep. Picture the sheep staring at you, staring at it.

meaning_mnemonic: If a <radical>sheep</radical> is having trouble trying to eat a fish with <radical>spikes</radical> on its <radical>fins</radical>, then the sheep probably has no <kanji>business</kanji> trying to eat it in the first place. Don’t sheep usually eat like, grass and stuff? What is this sheep doing trying to eat a fish with spikes on its fins? What silly business this is.
meaning_hint: Imagine this crazy sheep. Why is it trying to eat this fish? This sheep is blood crazed. Blood crazed for fish meat, especially the meat from fish with spikes on their fins. This crazed sheep means business.
reading_mnemonic: What’s this? The sheep is also trying to eat some <reading>gyo</reading>za (ぎょう) dumplings! Where will this sheep’s madness end? First spikey finned fish and now gyoza? This is some crazy <kanji>business</kanji>.
reading_hint: Imagine you’re at an Asian style restaurant and you just ordered a big plate of gyoza dumplings. Next thing you know, this crazy sheep busts through the front door and starts devouring all your gyoza! Where did this sheep come from and why does he love gyoza so much!?

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>tree</radical> marked with a <radical>yellow</radical> X on the <kanji>side</kanji> of the house is going to get cut down. You’ve marked it with a yellow X so the hired help knows which tree to cut down. There are a lot of trees on the side of the house, but the tree marked with a yellow X is the only one in danger of causing damage to your roof in the event of a storm.
meaning_hint: Picture the scene of a woman with a chainsaw cutting down this tree marked with a yellow X. Hear the sound of the chainsaw buzzing and the grinding of wood as it meets the side of the trunk. It’s very loud. Woodchips go flying everywhere.
reading_mnemonic: Wait, that woman with the chainsaw is <reading>Yoko</reading> (よこ) Ono! Yes, the same Yoko Ono who’s married to John Lennon of the Beatles. What’s she doing chopping down trees on the <kanji>side</kanji> of your house? Who can say. Silly Yoko.
reading_hint: Now picture the same scene as before only imagining Yoko Ono wielding that chainsaw. Maybe she’s dancing. Maybe there’s some Beatles music playing in the background. Either way it’s a strange sight – remember it.

meaning_mnemonic: If you <radical>lack</radical> a <radical>lip ring</radical> (or two in this case) it's going to make it way easier for you to <kanji>sing</kanji> a <kanji>song</kanji>.
meaning_hint: Imagine a song with lip rings. Then imagine one without. Sing them, pretending you have lip rings. It doesn't work as well.
reading_mnemonic: You're singing a <kanji>song</kanji> with all these lip rings in your mouth and you sound terrible. You're on the side of the road singing. People are freaking out. Finally, someone drives into you with their <reading>ca</reading>r (か).
reading_hint: Imagine yourself getting hit by this car. All the air flies out of you as you sing your <kanji>song</kanji>. You think "I shouldn't have tried to sing a song with all these lip rings..."

meaning_mnemonic: On the <radical>ground</radical> is a <radical>water</radical> <radical>drop</radical> you spilled, so I <kanji>request</kanji> you wipe it up. I would do it myself, but you're the one who spilled it, so I'm requesting you do it and take responsibility for your mistake.
meaning_hint: It's a simple request, really. Just wipe up that water drop off the ground.
reading_mnemonic: Oh, one more thing. I <kanji>request</kanji> that you wipe up the water with this <reading>cu</reading>cumber (きゅう).
reading_hint: "But cucumbers are already mostly water, this isn't going to absorb anything!" you cry. Well too bad. That's my request, so you better do it. Figure out how to make the cucumber work.

meaning_mnemonic:
A <radical>tsunami</radical> hit ancient <radical>China</radical> and formed the <kanji>Chinese</kanji> country we know now as... <kanji>China</kanji>!

Sometimes this kanji also means <kanji>man</kanji>. In fact, it used to refer specifically to people of the Han dynasty, but over time evolved into a term for men in specific contexts.
meaning_hint: Picture the world way far away, from space. You see a giant tsunami carve out a massive chunk of land to the west of Japan on the main continent. Slowly the tsunami waters recede, leaving the outline of China.
reading_mnemonic: You peer closer at <kanji>China</kanji> and see one man, Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (かん), leading his troops into the vast country, ready to conquer all the Chinese people living in China!
reading_hint: Khan is only one man, but watch as he takes China for himself. A tiny little flag with a horse on it is raised in the middle, for all of the Chinese people to see. Hmm, this could be a problem.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>sick</radical> stick of <radical>dynamite</radical> is going to be <kanji>sick</kanji> forever. Unfortunately there are no medicines that are effective on sticks of dynamite, so once they contract a sickness, they’re sick for good.
meaning_hint: Imagine if you were a sick stick of dynamite. Every time you sneezed you ran the risk of blowing up. It would be a terrifying way to live. Just imagine it.
reading_mnemonic: Being nervous all the time about spontaneously exploding would probably make you sweat profusely. And you know what sweating causes? <reading>B.O.</reading> (びょう). You’d be one smelly stick of dynamite. B.O. is a very unpleasant smell, and being <kanji>sick</kanji> is no excuse.
reading_hint: Picture this as your life. You could explode at any moment, you’re sick, and you have B.O. Nobody wants to be around you because you might explode and kill them, and you stink. What a terrible way to live!

meaning_mnemonic: If you get stabbed in the <radical>eye</radical> <radical>twenty</radical> times with <radical>bamboo</radical>, you’re going to have a hard time beginning to <kanji>calculate</kanji> where anything is. Taking a bamboo shoot to the eye is no pleasant experience, especially if done twenty times. You’d be blinded for sure. And a newly blinded person is going to have one heck of a time calculating where everything is without the power of sight.
meaning_hint: Imagine getting jabbed with a bamboo shoot. Now imagine getting jabbed in the eye with a bamboo shoot. It’s going to hurt. Try and calculate exactly how painful this would be and imagine it happening to you.
reading_mnemonic: Do you know how <reading>San</reading>ta-san (さん) punishes naughty boys and girls in Asia? He doesn’t give them coal, Santa-san tortures them with twenty bamboo jabs to the eye. Yikes. Do you know how Santa-san <kanji>calculate</kanji>s who is naughty and who is nice? By their school grades, of course.
reading_hint: Picture this evil Asian Santa-san, clad in blood red garments and brandishing pointed bamboo shoots in each hand. He’s a cold and calculating madman! You’d better start studying! Santa-san is watching!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>thread</radical> of <radical>winter</radical> and <radical>ice</radical> has brought this year to its <kanji>end</kanji>. Once you're in the long thread of winter and ice, you know the year will end soon.
meaning_hint: Picture the season of winter as a long thread, embalmed in ice. At the end of it is the year’s end. The thread of winter and ice brings you closure, it marks the end.
reading_mnemonic: Whenever winter <kanji>end</kanji>s, you take the thread covered in ice, and lace it into your <reading>shoe</reading> (しゅう).
reading_hint: This thread isn't just a metaphor, it's real! Feel the cold ice on it, as you lace it into your shoe. An age old tradition, the lacing of icy threads as winter ends. Your shoes will look so cool, or should I say… iced out.

meaning_mnemonic: If someone falls overboard while you're <radical>white</radical> <radical>water </radical>rafting, you can use a long piece of <radical>thread</radical> as a life <kanji>line</kanji>. Sure it might be thin, but a line of thread is better than nothing. Throw them a line and drag them back aboard! Those white water rapids are vicious.
meaning_hint: Imagine you're the person who fell overboard. The white water is rushing violently and it is deathly cold. Feel the water and freezing temperature on your skin. But look! Someone has thrown you a line of thread! You're saved!
reading_mnemonic: The person who threw you that <kanji>line</kanji> of thread is actually a <reading>cen</reading>taur (せん). How kind of him. After you are safe you hop on the centaur's back and ride around to get the wind to dry you off.
reading_hint: Coming out of the rushing water, this centaur is like an angel sent from heaven. He's just saved your life. Imagine the happiness and gratitude you feel towards this centaur as you are pulled to safety by that line of thread.

meaning_mnemonic: You find some <radical>white</radical> <radical>feathers</radical> and you want to <kanji>learn</kanji> more about where they came from and what they're made of.
meaning_hint: Picture yourself in a library poring through huge tomes on birds, feathers, and the history of white birds. You want to learn everything you can!
reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>learn</kanji> that you should tie these white feathers to your <reading>shoe</reading>s (しゅう). You do it before you learn what it will do, and then suddenly you're jump-flying out of the building.
reading_hint: Oh geez, oh no. You better learn how to control these shoes before you—CRASH!!! Welp, you just shot through a plane. You need to learn more before you act next time.

meaning_mnemonic: If you press your <radical>ear</radical> up to a <radical>gate</radical>, you’re likely to <kanji>hear</kanji> what’s going on on the other side. The other people on the other side won’t know you are listening to their conversation because you are so sneaky and clever. They’ve no idea you’re on the other side of the gate hearing every word they say.
meaning_hint: I’m sure you’ve pressed your ear up against a wall, door, or gate at sometime to hear what’s going on on the other side of it. Remember back to a time you did this and how sneaky you felt listening in on people without them knowing. You sneaky frood, you.
reading_mnemonic: From the other side of the gate, you <kanji>hear</kanji> one of the people on the other side start to play a song on a recorder. You recognize the song as “Hot Cross <reading>Bun</reading>s (ぶん).” You haven’t heard this song in a long time. “Hot cross buns… hot cross buns~”
reading_hint: I’m sure many of you were forced to play the recorder in school at some point and were made to play the song known as hot cross buns. Picture yourself playing this song and remember the melody when you see this kanji.

meaning_mnemonic: A violent <radical>tsunami</radical> causes <radical>flowers</radical> to be ripped from the branches of trees and they swirl around and <radical>kiss</radical> your face gently as they <kanji>fall</kanji>. With the tsunami came a great windy storm that blew many flowers all about. It’s a pretty sight amongst all the destruction.
meaning_hint: Imagine being out in this tsunami induced storm. You can feel the rain and wind on your skin – you’re wet, cold, and scared. But you see some flowers being blown to the ground and you are mesmerized by the dance they do on the wind before they finally fall to the ground.
reading_mnemonic: You want to save these flowers you see <kanji>fall</kanji>ing in around you, so you take out a drying <reading>rack</reading> (らく) and place them carefully on it. Now whenever you feel scared, you can look at the flowers on this rack and you won't be scared anymore.
reading_hint: Imagine running around catching the flowers as they fall. Imagine placing each little petal onto the rack to keep it safe and dry.

meaning_mnemonic: In the <radical>world</radical> of <radical>flowers</radical> and <radical>tree</radical>s, the most important thing is the <kanji>leaf</kanji>. <kanji>Leaves</kanji> are how flowers and trees get their nutrients from the sun!
meaning_hint: Leaves, no matter how little, are the most important thing in the world for them.
reading_mnemonic: Picture a little flower working really hard to grow its first leaf. The <kanji>leaf</kanji> pops out and it shouts, "<reading>Ha</reading> (は)!"
reading_hint: は is the sound of a leaf coming into existence. Whenever you see a plant from now on, hear the little ha sound it makes when each leaf pops out of its body.

meaning_mnemonic: If you're <radical>stand</radical>ing under a <radical>tree</radical> and you <radical>see</radical> your <kanji>parent</kanji>, it's a good chance for a moment of <kanji>intimacy</kanji>.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself standing in the shade of a beautiful, big, old tree. You see your parent walk past and shout out to them. They come and join you, and it's like the two of you are the only two people in the world right now. That's intimacy.
reading_mnemonic: Standing under the tree, you go to give your <kanji>parent</kanji> a big hug, but you manage to bang your <reading>shin</reading> (しん)  on a huge tree root. Your parent pulls you in for a warm hug and rubs your shin. Despite the pain, it becomes an unforgettable "shin-timate" moment.
reading_hint: Busting your shins on things really hurts. I'm sure you've hit your shins on coffee tables and the like all your life. Remember that pain and think how much worse it would be banging your bare shins on pointy tree roots just when you were enjoying a moment of parental intimacy. Not enjoyable.

meaning_mnemonic: What you <radical>say</radical> between <radical>five</radical> <radical>mouth</radical>s is a <kanji>language</kanji>. As long as there are five different people saying these same words with their five mouths, it's considered its own language.
meaning_hint: Picture these five mouths saying the same language to each other. They can understand each other! The mouths are smiling and laughing too.
reading_mnemonic: Another mouth joins in speaking the <kanji>language</kanji>, but it's green and scaled and... it's <reading>Go</reading>dzilla's (ご) mouth! Godzilla speaks this language too.
reading_hint: Godzilla speaks a language some people understand! You wish you knew this earlier, then you might have been able to stop some of his destruction. Try to say, "Hey Godzilla, please stop destroying my city," in his language. It's a lot of growling and yelling. He doesn't seem to understand you. You better practice your pronunciation.

meaning_mnemonic: You have to <radical>say</radical> what you’re <radical>sell</radical>ing because people don’t like to <kanji>read</kanji>. If they walk right by and don’t read, you better say what you have for sale so they’ll know! Read it out loud to them.
meaning_hint: Imagine reading what you have for sale out loud to people walking by because they’re too lazy to read it for themselves.
reading_mnemonic: What are you forced to <kanji>read</kanji> aloud to sell? <reading>Yo-</reading>yo (よ) instructions! You’d think they’d be self explanatory, but there are actually a lot of rules and tricks that you have to read to get good at yo-yoing. Read all of these out loud so you can sell them.
reading_hint: Imagine reading through your list of yo-yo tricks. Do you know how to pronounce those weird yo-yo names?

meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>say</radical> something about the <radical>circumference</radical> of this area. You've looked around this whole area, making a big circle around it, because you are trying to <kanji>investigate</kanji> something that happened here. You also say this thing in a really quiet <kanji>tone</kanji> of voice, because you don't want the person or thing you're investigating to know you're on to them.
meaning_hint: Because the radical <radical>circumference</radical> is in play, you can think of the crime scene you're investigating as a statue of a giant globe, and you're doing a circumference around it. Then, in the reading, we'll think about what you'll <radical>say</radical>.
reading_mnemonic: "I came here to <kanji>investigate</kanji> this place, and I did indeed find out who the criminal is... it's none other than Mrs. <reading>Chou</reading> (ちょう)!"
reading_hint: From what you know about evil Mrs. Chou, you probably could have guessed it was her. The "Circumference Investigation" is now over, though you do still have to catch the perp, Mrs. Chou.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Run</radical> into <radical>oneself</radical> in a dream and you'll definitely <kanji>wake up</kanji>.
meaning_hint: If you run into yourself, it really messes you up, you know? You won't be able to handle what you're seeing so you have to wake up.
reading_mnemonic: If one runs into oneself and you don't <kanji>wake up</kanji>, just look down at your waist. If you're wearing an <reading>o</reading>bi (お) you know it's a dream and you'll eventually wake up. If you aren't wearing an obi then it isn't a dream and you don't have anything to wake up from.
reading_hint: Your obi is like a special object you only have in dreams. If you have your obi, it's okay, it's a dream and you can wake up now! Make sure you memorize exactly how it feels so dream-you can't trick you or something.

meaning_mnemonic: If you’ve been walking all day, nobody is going to want to <radical>kiss</radical> your <radical>foot</radical> if you’ve been walking barefoot down a dirt <kanji>road</kanji>. Your feet are filthy, sweaty, and stinky. Nobody is going to want to kiss those feet.
meaning_hint: Imagine kissing someone’s foot. Now imagine kissing someone’s foot after they’ve been walking down a dirt road for hours. It’s disgusting. Smell the stench of dirt and sweat wafting up into your nostrils as the foot approaches your lips. It’s wretched.
reading_mnemonic: What was this person walking down again? Oh, that’s right – a <reading>ro</reading>ad (ろ). They were walking down a dirt <kanji>road</kanji>.
reading_hint: Walking down a dirt road barefoot like this is a sure way to dirty up your feet. Feel the dirt, rocks, and twigs under your feet. The road is hard and dry and is not making your journey very comfortable at all.

meaning_mnemonic: If your <radical>car</radical> runs into a <radical>cloud</radical> you'll <kanji>revolve</kanji> around it instead of going straight through. Clouds are really hard to see through, so even though you're trying not to, you revolve in a tight circle up and around the cloud anyway.
meaning_hint: Imagine driving your car around and around the cloud, instead of going through it. At least it's soft and cool.
reading_mnemonic: You have to <kanji>revolve</kanji> around the cloud <reading>ten</reading> (てん) times before it disappears and you're able to go through.
reading_hint: Unfortunately, not long after you get through that cloud another one comes down and gets in your way. Now you're counting each revolution, one... two... three... all the way up to ten.

meaning_mnemonic: For a <radical>car</radical>, a <radical>tombstone</radical> is <kanji>lightweight</kanji>. Cars are very strong, you see, so something heavy like a tombstone is no match for them. All cars find tombstones to be <kanji>light</kanji> and easy to transport.
meaning_hint: Picture yourself trying to move a huge slab tombstone. It’s difficult, no? I bet you wish you had a car or some other vehicle to make the process much less painful. Your arms are getting sore from carrying the tombstone and you’re getting sweaty and hot from all the work. What you would do for a car with air conditioning.
reading_mnemonic: What do you wish you had to transport this tombstone? Oh, that’s right, a car. So you need some kind of <reading>car</reading> <reading>loo</reading>phole (かる). If you had a car, this tombstone moving business would be no problem. To cars, tombstones are naught but <kanji>lightweight</kanji> pebbles! But the rules say you can't use cars to carry tombstones, so you need to find a car loophole.
reading_hint: Remember all that hard work you were doing before and how you got all sweaty and gross? Now imagine yourself inside of a nice car with air conditioning, and the tombstone in the trunk. It feels great doesn’t it? The air conditioning is perfect, and driving a car is much easier than carrying a tombstone around. Thank goodness you found a car loophole in the tombstone carrying rules.

meaning_mnemonic: You blast your <radical>music</radical> loud so it causes a <radical>landslide</radical>, revealing the perfect soil for <kanji>farming</kanji>! Musically moved dirt is perfect for <kanji>agriculture</kanji>.
meaning_hint: Imagine slowly turning up your big boombox until your ears hurt and the ground beneath your feet is vibrating with the beat. Soon you and the boombox are sliding with all of the earth down the hill and onto your farmland. Hooray, now the farming can begin!
reading_mnemonic: The first person to come up with this <kanji>farming</kanji> method was <reading>No</reading>stradamus (のう), the famous seer and prophecy man. He predicted humans of the future would use special "yell cubes" to "move that good earth."
reading_hint: Picture Nostradamus flailing his arms and trying to explain his vision to the farmers at the time. He knows that if they listen their farming techniques will improve, but they're looking at him like he's nuts.

meaning_mnemonic: You jump on your <radical>scooter</radical> with a big <radical>bundle</radical> to go as <kanji>fast</kanji> as you can! You have a bundle of pizzas in here, and they need to be delivered as fast as you can get them there!
meaning_hint: Imagine how fast you can go on your scooter holding this bundle. It's way faster than trying to go on foot, that's for sure!
reading_mnemonic: You were going so <kanji>fast</kanji>, you only put on <reading>sock</reading>s (そく). So now you're barreling down the street at top speeds in just your sad, white socks.
reading_hint: Imagine riding the scooter as fast as you can in just your socks. You can feel the wind pulling them off your feet!

meaning_mnemonic: You give your <radical>scooter</radical> to a <radical>turkey</radical> so that it can <kanji>advance</kanji>. The turkey was trying and failing to walk through a crowded street, so out of the goodness of your heart you gave it a scooter so it could advance.
meaning_hint: Imagine picking up the turkey and putting it on your scooter. Of course, you give it your helmet as well, safety first.
reading_mnemonic: You wave as the turkey <kanji>advance</kanji>s into the street at top speeds, collides with a car, and scrapes up its <reading>shin</reading>s (しん) almost immediately. Ah!
reading_hint: Silly turkey, you can't advance that fast, of course you'll hurt your shins. It's better to advance slowly, but I guess I couldn't expect you to know that.

meaning_mnemonic: While riding your <radical>scooter</radical>, you bang your <radical>forehead</radical> on the <radical>car</radical> in front. Your scooter's wrecked, so you have to <kanji>carry</kanji> it home. You'll need a lot of <kanji>luck</kanji> to get that scooter home safely.
meaning_hint: Imagine trying to carry your scooter down a busy road, with all the cars whizzing past. Your forehead is still hurting from that nasty bang. Good luck!
reading_mnemonic: As you <kanji>carry</kanji> the scooter, your <kanji>luck</kanji> turns, and it starts to rain, so you pull out your <reading>um</reading>brella (うん). Now you're holding your scooter, your forehead, and an umbrella.
reading_hint: It's hard enough to carry a scooter in heavy traffic, but now you have to try to keep yourself and it dry with an umbrella too.

meaning_mnemonic: You don't want to keep all the <radical>alcohol</radical> to yourself (<radical>oneself</radical>), so you <kanji>distribute</kanji> it to all of your friends. Heck, not just your friends, to everyone you can find!
meaning_hint: Don't be that person who keeps the alcohol all to themselves. Distribute it to all of the legally-aged people you know!
reading_mnemonic:
As you <kanji>distribute</kanji> the alcohol you say a <reading>hai</reading>ku (はい):

Here you go my friends
Alcohol for everyone
Never drink alone
reading_hint: This becomes the haiku you say before every party, every potluck, and every night out at the bar. You even get it tattoo'd to your arm.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> is an <radical>alcohol</radical>ic beverage containing a lot of <kanji>alcohol</kanji>. It’s 3 different kinds of rums, pineapple juice, and grenadine. It’ll hit you like a tsunami though. This alcoholic drink has a kick to it.
meaning_hint: It’s made with spiced rum, coconut rum, and dark rum. Imagine yourself on a sandy beach drinking this cocktail. Feel the sun on your face and the wind in your hair as you sip on this fruity and rummy alcoholic beverage known as a tsunami. You could even picture an actual tsunami in the water coming right for you. I wouldn’t recommend it though—actual tsunami are scary, not drinkable and delicious.
reading_mnemonic: As you lie on this beach, the <kanji>alcohol</kanji> keeps coming down a <reading>chu</reading>te (しゅ), straight into your mouth. You can feel the sand in your toes and the alcohol sliding down your throat from this special tsunami chute.
reading_hint: Picture the alcohol flowing down this long chute from somewhere far away. You try to see where it's coming from, but all you can see is this long, long chute stretching along the entire beach, until it disappears into the distance. You should probably be concerned that you're nonstop drinking alcohol from a random chute, but it tastes so good!

meaning_mnemonic: You look at some <radical>gold</radical> and notice a <radical>fault</radical> in it. You scrape at the fault and see that it's just sprayed with gold paint. It's not gold, it's (comparatively) worthless <kanji>iron</kanji>!
meaning_hint: You think you've found a ton of gold bars! Imagine being so happy about this. Then, imagine your heart dropping in your chest when you notice the fault. Then, it dropping down even farther when you figure out it's merely iron.
reading_mnemonic: Do you know that movie, <reading>Tetsu</reading>o (てつ) the <kanji>Iron</kanji> Man? We talked about it on Tofugu a while back. It’s one of the wackiest Japanese movies of all time. If you don’t know about Tetsuo the Iron Man, you should definitely look it up (if you aren't averse to horror/violent films). Tetsuo is one of the most insane movies in the history of ever.
reading_hint: Watch a trailer on YouTube for Tetsuo the Iron Man. Go ahead, do it now – I’ll wait. Did you watch it? Remember that nonsense every time you see this kanji.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>gate</radical> with a <radical>lantern</radical> is <kanji>open</kanji> for you. That's convenient, since it's pretty dark out and you might not have seen the open gate without the lantern's help.
meaning_hint: Imagine being a traveler, walking around the outside of a huge walled city. You really need to get inside but all of the gates are closed. Finally, you see a single, bright lantern marking the open gate! What a relief.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>open</kanji> gate is in the water though, so you'll need a <reading>kay</reading>ak (かい) to get in. Luckily, you've been carrying your kayak with you just in case.
reading_hint: Imagine kayaking in the dark toward an open gate. Finally, you've made it!

meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>building</radical> has a <radical>roof</radical> and will teach you about the <radical>origin</radical> of many things. It's an <kanji>institution</kanji>!
meaning_hint: Institutions are places of learning, but they have to be a physical place with a roof and all that. If you're learning out in a field somewhere, that's probably not a proper institution.
reading_mnemonic: What does <kanji>institution</kanji> start with? In (いん)!
reading_hint: Just remember, it's an IN-stitution, and you'll know this reading easy-peasy.

meaning_mnemonic: You chase a <radical>turkey</radical> up a <radical>tree</radical> to <kanji>collect</kanji> it. At least, you will once you've <kanji>gather</kanji>ed enough turkeys into this one tree.
meaning_hint: Collect another turkey, send it flying and gobbling up into the tree next to the other one.
reading_mnemonic: Once you've <kanji>collect</kanji>ed enough turkeys, you're going to turn them into a <reading>shoe</reading> (しゅう). Maybe even two shoes, but that will mean <kanji>gather</kanji>ing even more turkeys!
reading_hint: Picture the nice, feathered shoes you'll be able to make once you've gathered all of these turkeys together. Ohoho, you can't wait! Go collect another turkey!

meaning_mnemonic: Did you know that those strange <radical>geoduck</radical> creatures were once used to make <kanji>page</kanji>s? Okay maybe not, but it makes for a memorable image!
meaning_hint: Imagine the strange, gooey books you'd end up with if you used geoducks for pages. Now imagine flicking through one of those books, and getting the slimy geoduck residue on your hands as you look at the pages.
reading_mnemonic: A <kanji>page</kanji> is a <reading>page</reading> (ページ).
reading_hint: Since the reading comes from the English word "page", this one shouldn't be too hard to remember, especially if you've already come across it in katakana.

meaning_mnemonic: If a <radical>geoduck</radical> eats lots of <radical>beans</radical>, its <kanji>head</kanji> will grow larger. To a geoduck, beans are a brain food, so by eating beans, a geoduck’s head will grow incredibly large. Geoducks already look strange enough as it is, let alone with engorged heads.
meaning_hint: Imagine, if you will, a geoduck. Now imagine that same geoduck with a massive head. It looks ridiculous, and more disgusting than ever. It’s actually really creeping you out, because the head keeps getting larger as the geoduck eats more beans. Ew.
reading_mnemonic: As the geoduck eats more and more beans, its <kanji>head</kanji> gets bigger and bigger until finally the geoduck’s head explodes like an <reading>atomi</reading>c (あたま) bomb. BOOM! Geoduck parts go flying everywhere and pieces of the geoduck’s massive head float to the ground as atomic fallout.
reading_hint: Remember how gross geoducks are? Of course you do. Now imagine one exploding right in front of you. You’ve got geoduck mess all over yourself. It’s gross, slimy, sticky, and covering you from head to toe. It’s wretched.

meaning_mnemonic: Here you <radical>stand</radical>, a <radical>hair</radical>’s breadth away from the edge of a <radical>cliff</radical>, when out of nowhere a <radical>geoduck</radical> slaps you right in the <kanji>face</kanji>. Geoducks are gross, and you back away from the edge of the cliff you were standing but a hair’s breadth away from just before. Your face is all gooey from the geoduck’s slimy residue.
meaning_hint: Imagine being slapped in the face with a geoduck. It’s probably one of the worst things that could ever happen to someone. Those things are disgusting. Now you have geoduck goo all over your face. It’s sticky and slimy and gross.
reading_mnemonic: But where did that geoduck come from anyway? As you turn around from the cliff edge, wiping the goop from your <kanji>face</kanji> and out of your eyes, you see an angry <reading>cow</reading> (かお). This cow is the one who hit you in the face with this geoduck. I know not the reason, but this cow is most definitely not happy with you.
reading_hint: Cows are big animals. So you probably got hit in the face with that geoduck pretty hard. Feel the geoduck shaped welt starting to form on the side of your face. It’s very painful and stings a lot.

meaning_mnemonic: You can <radical>eat</radical> all you want, but you'll still <radical>lack</radical> something to <kanji>drink</kanji>. You can't live just from eating, you have to drink things too!
meaning_hint: Imagine eating and eating and lacking a delicious, cold, thirst-quenching drink. Your mouth is dry. You have to drink something, anything!
reading_mnemonic: You get desperate for a <kanji>drink</kanji> and put some <reading>no</reading>ri (の) seaweed in a blender, trying to create a drink of your own.
reading_hint: Luckily, this nori isn't dried and pressed like they usually are, and you manage to make a bright green nori drink. You gulp it down, and even though it tastes like the ocean, it hits the spot!

meaning_mnemonic: When a <radical>bird</radical> opens its <radical>mouth</radical>, you’re most likely to hear a <kanji>chirp</kanji>. This is how birds communicate. They open their mouths and let out a series of chirps. Chirp chirp chirp!
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself out in the wilderness on a sunny spring day. The weather is perfect and the scenery is beautiful. The only sound you can hear is the chirp of birds throughout the woods around you. It’s very peaceful.
reading_mnemonic: The best way to experience the <kanji>chirp</kanji> chirping of birds is to offer them <reading>na</reading>chos(な). Birds love nachos so much, it's a guaranteed way to make them chirp with delight.
reading_hint: Picture yourself surrounded by birds of all kinds, handing out nachos. Just listen to their happy chirping. They're sitting on your arms, shoulders, and even your head, trying to get closer to the nachos. That chirping is so loud!
